comments:
This course will survey the discipline of molecular genetics. Two broad areas will be considered: 1) Molecular Biology: DNA replication, transcription, translation, regulation of gene expression in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, and genomics and 2) Genetics: basic Mendelian & molecular genetics. The class requires a prerequisite of BIOL 101 or 121.

Students found the class relatively interesting but a bit unorganized. Some were overwhelmed by the amount of material covered. Others learned a lot in terms of experimental techniques and felt that the course expanded previous knowledge on the fundamentals of molecular biology. Others said that much of the material was targeted towards memorization.

Students found the professors truly knowledgeable, but found that they didn’t necessarily explain things that were important for the exam.

Most students found that the exams were not good evaluators of students’ knowledge (unfairly written and covering concepts not discussed in class). The exams were very challenging and questions on the exams were difficult to decipher/understand.

This course surveys the discipline of Molecular Genetics. This includes two broad areas in molecular biology and genetics.

Students found the course to be “interesting but very challenging.” Recorded lectures were “very helpful” since the course is offered early in the day. One student found this to be “the single most interesting, stimulating course that [he had] taken at Penn.” Some found the class to be very well organized, while others had difficulty with the Blackboard site shared between two professors.

Dr. Gallagher received favorable reviews from her students. She was “very accessible,” and her style was described as “knowledgeable and engaging.” Professor Gallagher was “easy to follow and understand in lecture.” One student described her as being "excellent."

BIOL 221 was “so very hard,” one student wrote. Another noted: “Little work outside of studying for exams was required, although the amount of information on the exams could seem overwhelming.” The exams were “challenging” and sometimes “difficult to decipher.” One student explained that most of the exams were based on memorization.

This course surveys the discipline of molecular genetics. Two broad areas are considered: 1) Molecular Biology: DNA replication, transcription, translation, regulation of gene expression in both prokaryotic and eukaryotic systems, and genomics and 2) Genetics: basic Mendelian & molecular genetics.

Students felt that a “wide range of topics were discussed in fair detail” and the course “definitely prepared students for further learning in molecular biology/genetics.”

Students felt Professor Laakso was “enthusiastic about the subject,” “engaging,” and “willing to meet with students and help them with any unclear material.” Students found Professor Laakso to be “well-spoken and always incredibly well-prepared for class.” Students reported that Professor Laakso used numerous slides for her lectures.

Students found the course “challenging.” Students found that the exams were “difficult but mostly fair,” although others felt that exam material “did not always correspond well with what was learned in class.” This course has a prerequisite of BIOL101 or 121.

*8 respondents
